slides.pacing: 15 seconds — read title, let it land, move on
slides.title: Orchestrator
slides.subtitle: Self-Improving Engineering Workflows

content.tagline: Skills are the atomic primitive. Everything else composes from skills.

slides.speakerNotes: Quick title. Don't linger. Say: 'I want to show you something we've been building. It starts with a question.' Then advance.
slides.voiceAlignment: Understated. Let the subtitle do the work. No hype.

slides.purpose: Create recognition — the audience should nod at every bullet
slides.pacing: 90 seconds — read each pain point, pause for recognition
slides.title: Sound familiar?

bullets: Team A does thorough code reviews. Team B rubber-stamps.
Your deployment process lives in one senior engineer's head.
That engineer leaves. The process leaves with them.
Your 'best practices' wiki has 200 pages. Nobody reads it.
Quality gates exist in CI. They get skipped when it's Friday at 4pm.
The same bugs keep happening across different teams.
content.bottom_line: Your engineering practices are scattered, undocumented, and non-compounding.

slides.speakerNotes: Go slow here. Each bullet should land. Watch for nods — that's your audience connecting. The bottom line reframes the scattered problems as one systemic issue.
slides.voiceAlignment: Empathetic, direct. No blame. Just recognition of a shared reality.

slides.purpose: Introduce the central concept — skills as atomic primitive
slides.pacing: 75 seconds — explain the concept, then contrast with status quo
slides.title: What if your engineering practices were code?

content.concept: A skill is a versioned, executable unit of engineering practice.

contrast.after: Versioned skill that improves through use
Documented process with references and examples
Enforced step in a quality-gated workflow

slides.speakerNotes: This is the 'aha' slide. The contrast table does the heavy lifting. Pause after each row. The key insight: skills aren't just docs — they're executable, composable, and they get better.
slides.voiceAlignment: Clear and precise. Present the idea without overselling it.

slides.purpose: Make the concept concrete — show what a skill actually looks like
slides.pacing: 90 seconds — walk through the structure, show a real example
slides.title: Anatomy of a Skill

items.role: The instruction set — YAML frontmatter + structured Markdown

example.heading: Example: the 'implement' skill
example.frontmatter:
name: implement
phase: IMPLEMENT
category: core
version: 1.0.0
depends_on: [spec, scaffold]
tags: [coding, core-workflow]
example.description: 7-step process: understand spec → plan order → data layer → service layer → API layer → UI layer → verify & test

slides.speakerNotes: Show the directory structure first, then zoom into a real skill. The 'implement' skill is a good example because everyone understands what implementation is. Point out: this isn't a doc — it has dependencies, a version, and a defined process.
slides.voiceAlignment: Technical but accessible. Walk through it like showing a colleague your code.

slides.purpose: Show breadth — 38 skills covering the full engineering lifecycle
slides.pacing: 60 seconds — quick scan, don't read every skill
slides.title: 38 Skills. Full Lifecycle.

categories.name: Core
categories.highlights: architect, implement, code-review, deploy, test-generation, security-audit, scaffold, spec, requirements

content.callout: You can create your own. Every skill follows the same structure.

slides.speakerNotes: Don't read the list. Let them scan. Emphasize: 22 core skills cover requirements through deployment. Then hit the callout: these are a starting library. You'd add your own team-specific skills.
slides.voiceAlignment: Confident but not boastful. The number speaks for itself.

slides.purpose: Show how skills compose into workflows — the engineering loop
slides.pacing: 90 seconds — walk through the flow diagram step by step
slides.title: Loops: Skills in Sequence

content.definition: A loop composes skills into a phased workflow with quality gates.

engineeringLoop.name: Engineering Loop v3.0.0
engineeringLoop.phases: INIT → SCAFFOLD → IMPLEMENT → TEST → VERIFY → VALIDATE → DOCUMENT → REVIEW → SHIP → COMPLETE
engineeringLoop.flow_description: Requirements and spec → architecture and scaffolding → implementation → test generation → automated verification → human validation + security audit → documentation → code review → deployment → retrospective

content.composability: The Proposal Loop reuses 4 skills from the Engineering Loop. New workflows compose from the existing library.

slides.speakerNotes: This is the centerpiece diagram. Walk through left to right. Point out the gate icons between phases. Key message: this isn't just a checklist — it's an execution engine with enforced gates. Mention composability: the proposal loop shares skills.
slides.voiceAlignment: Enthusiastic but measured. Let the diagram carry the weight.

slides.purpose: Explain how quality is enforced — gates are the differentiator
slides.pacing: 75 seconds — explain gate types, show the enforcement model
slides.title: Gates That Actually Gate

content.premise: A gate blocks progression until its criteria are met. No exceptions.

gateTypes.behavior: Requires explicit approval. Spec, architecture, validation, code review.
Passes if automated checks pass — build, tests, lint.
Auto-passes if no target configured (e.g., deploy gate with no deploy target).

content.enforcement: The execution engine will not advance past a gate. Period. No 'skip for now'. No 'we'll fix it later'.
content.humanInLoop: Engineers retain final authority. AI assists — humans approve.

slides.speakerNotes: This slide answers the skeptic's question: 'How is this different from a checklist I'll ignore?' Answer: the execution engine enforces it. Also pre-empt the AI-fear objection: humans approve at every human gate. AI doesn't replace judgment — it assists between gates.
slides.voiceAlignment: Direct and firm. This is a key differentiator. State it plainly.

slides.purpose: Show the self-improving aspect — memory compounds learning
slides.pacing: 75 seconds — explain the hierarchy, show what gets remembered
slides.title: Memory: Learning That Compounds

level1.name: Orchestrator Memory
level1.scope: Global patterns and decisions across all projects

level3.name: Skill Memory
level3.scope: Per-skill calibration, success rates, execution history

whatGetsRemembered: Decisions — ADR-style records with context, rationale, consequences
Patterns — named solutions with confidence levels and usage counts
Calibration — estimate vs. actual, with multipliers that auto-adjust
Handoffs — session continuity so context survives between sessions
content.keyInsight: New team members inherit the accumulated knowledge of everyone who used the system before them.

slides.speakerNotes: The memory hierarchy diagram should be the visual anchor. Key selling point for a DevEx team: this is how you stop losing institutional knowledge. The handoff feature means context survives between sessions — no more 'let me get you up to speed' meetings.
slides.voiceAlignment: Thoughtful. This is the 'long game' argument. Let it breathe.

slides.purpose: Show the feedback loop — skills get better through use
slides.pacing: 75 seconds — walk the cycle, give a concrete example
slides.title: Skills Improve Through Use

cycle: Execute a skill in a loop
LearningService analyzes logs for improvement signals
Applied improvement bumps the skill version

example.scenario: You run the code-review skill. It misses a concurrency issue.
example.feedback: improve: code-review missed a race condition in the async handler
example.result: Skill versions from 1.2.0 → 1.3.0. CHANGELOG updated. Next execution includes the new pattern.

content.tagline: The 10th time you run a skill, it's better than the 1st.

slides.speakerNotes: The cycle diagram is visual. But the concrete example is what lands. Walk through: you noticed a gap, you typed one line of feedback, and the skill improved and versioned up. That's the self-improving promise made concrete.
slides.voiceAlignment: Demonstrative. Show cause and effect. Keep it grounded.

slides.purpose: Satisfy the technical curiosity — architecture and numbers
slides.pacing: 60 seconds — quick architecture overview, key stats
slides.title: Under the Hood

layers: MCP Interface — 105+ tools, any MCP client can drive the system
Services — SkillRegistry, LoopComposer, ExecutionEngine, MemoryService, LearningService
Storage — Git + JSON files. No database. Version control is free.

content.techStack: TypeScript 5.6 · Node 18+ · Express · MCP SDK · Zod · ~10K LOC
content.dashboard: Real-time monitoring: Next.js 15 + React 19. Execution timeline, skill browser, gate approval UI, live SSE metrics.

slides.speakerNotes: Quick slide. Engineers will want to know the stack. Hit the key points: MCP-native (standard protocol, not proprietary), file-based (no infra to manage), TypeScript (they can read and modify the source). Mention the dashboard exists but suggest a live demo as follow-up.
slides.voiceAlignment: Efficient. Facts, not commentary. Let the numbers land.

slides.purpose: Build trust by being transparent about limitations and maturity
slides.pacing: 90 seconds — balance strengths and limitations honestly
slides.title: Honest Assessment

whatWorks: 38 production-quality skill definitions covering the full lifecycle
Execution engine with enforced quality gates
3-tier memory system with pattern and calibration tracking
Composable loops — build new workflows from existing skills
105+ MCP tools — deep integration with Claude
whatsEarly: Requires Claude / MCP client — not a standalone GUI
Runs locally — no multi-team cloud sync yet
The 38 skills are a starting library — you'll customize them
adoptionPath: Week 1: Install. Explore the skill library. Run the engineering loop on a small feature.
Weeks 2–3: Customize skills to your team's patterns.
Month 1: Supervised mode. Human approves every gate. Build trust.
Month 2+: Increase autonomy for trusted workflows.
Ongoing: Feedback compounds. Skills evolve. Memory grows.

slides.speakerNotes: This is the trust-building slide. Lead with strengths, then be genuinely honest about limitations. The adoption path gives them a concrete mental model. Key message: this is early but architecturally sound, and the investment to customize is how you make it yours.
slides.voiceAlignment: Candid. No hedging, no apologizing. Just honest.

slides.purpose: Soft call to action — invite a hands-on session
slides.pacing: 30 seconds — state the offer, open to questions
slides.title: Let's Try It

content.offer: Pick a real feature your team is building. We'll run the engineering loop on it — together.
whatTheyGet: See every phase and gate in action on your actual code
Explore and customize skills to match your patterns
Judge for yourself whether it fits

slides.speakerNotes: Keep it short. The offer is concrete: pick a real feature, we run the loop. This is more compelling than 'schedule a follow-up.' End with 'Questions?' and stop talking.
slides.voiceAlignment: Warm, confident, brief. Don't oversell. The rest of the deck already made the case.
